{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3659531,"name":"Ohad","username":"Ohad_shulman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-21T22:25:28.227Z","cooked":"

how do i calculate the ratios on a dual motor planetary differential where the sun and ring gears are powered. i need to be able to find the speed and torque of the planet gears and the carrier no matter what percent of power is going in each, assuming the sun and ring gears motors are identical

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-21T22:25:28.227Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":350,"reads":286,"readers_count":285,"score":1822.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/change-one-letter-of-a-thread-title/466278/161","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Change one letter of a thread title","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659551,"name":"Patrick","username":"Patrick3357","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-21T23:14:52.814Z","cooked":"

You sir are going way outside common FRC practices. Outside most ME’s common practice really. You have two options: google the formulas, you should be able to find some college ME teaching materials with formulas for various ratios, or calculate it manually. Planetary gear sets are not some special magic, if you can do a little geometry and calculate ratios from normal spur gears, you can calculate planetary gear ratios if you put your mind to it.

Either way, it’s stunning that this is a question at the high school level.

I’m going to ask the question this way:

Why do both the sun and ring gears need to be powered? And why separately?

It’s pretty common to use a dual-powered planetary differential in electric or hybrid vehicles to couple two power sources and do so efficiently. See this journal article, for example. Not sure of the use case on an FTC robot. Seems like too much complexity for not enough efficiency gain. For getting every mile out of a battery charge on an electric car, definitely.

This is an ftc project but it’s just an experiment I’m doing. I’m planning to use a planetary differential to control the angle and extension of the slide with two motors, and then do the same thing on both sides and replace the slide with a differential slide. so that the carriers control the angle and the planet gears control the extension. Chatgpt doesn’t have any clue on how this works and I couldn’t find the answer anywhere else. My last resort is to go and read a full mech eng hand book

Wdym? I’m trying to factor in the rotation of both the sun and ring gears and I can’t find a simple equation

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T04:40:06.303Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":141,"readers_count":140,"score":33.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52597,"username":"Patrick3357","name":"Patrick","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/patrick3357/{size}/169915_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659910,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T06:00:44.328Z","cooked":"

I’m going to be quite blunt:

What you’re proposing is not going to work as you’ve written it. And when it’s corrected, it still won’t be simple–just simpler than I was thinking.

Ohad_shulman:

so that the carriers control the angle and the planet gears control the extension.

This ain’t possible. No way no how. Because the planet gears and their carrier are connected, you pretty much can’t take power directly off the planet gears without having an extra carrier of some form, or an extra gear that is powered right off the planet without blocking either the planet or the carrier… so no. I’m going to assume that you misspoke and are referring to the ring gear instead of the planets.

Let’s try this again: You want to use a single planetary gearbox, where the sun gear (shaft, carriers, etc) drives angle and the ring gear (outer shell, essentially) drives extension–or vice versa. For our purposes, it doesn’t matter which way. Two motors go in, two motions come out.

Equations: Epicyclic gearing - Wikipedia

You’ll want to note that for a multi-stage gearbox, the output of one stage is the input of the next stage. So if you have 3 stages, you’ll need: Motor outputs (S1 inputs), S1 outputs (S2 inputs), S2 outputs (S3 inputs) in order to get the actual output. I think there’s enough information there for you to derive the equations you’ll need.

And, just to put you on the right track for the % of power problem you posed at the start of this: It’s going to be much better if you focus on speed and torque separately.

One final note: The packaging–how this gearbox is mounted–is going to be much harder than most FRC gearboxes, due to the ring gear rotating. Impossible? Not by a long shot. Just difficult-ish. When you figure out the weight, compare it to using two separate planetaries.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T06:00:44.328Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":134,"readers_count":133,"score":61.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epicyclic_gearing","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Epicyclic gearing - Wikipedia","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":72030,"username":"Ohad_shulman","name":"Ohad","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/9","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659912,"name":"Ohad","username":"Ohad_shulman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T06:14:24.946Z","cooked":"

It is in fact possible. The carrier is connected to the planet gears using bearings so that the planet gears will be able to spin around themselves and the carrier will spin when the planet gears orbit the sun gears. I’m trying to find the speed the planet gears will spin in these scenarios and with what torque

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T06:14:24.946Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":115,"readers_count":114,"score":28.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/10","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659915,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T06:22:22.522Z","cooked":"

You’re going to need to put a picture up, so that I can point out the errors in someone’s understanding. Most likely yours, because the carrier is not independently rotating from the planet gears.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T06:22:22.522Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":110,"readers_count":109,"score":27.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":72030,"username":"Ohad_shulman","name":"Ohad","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659918,"name":"Ohad","username":"Ohad_shulman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T06:37:13.852Z","cooked":"

im saying i will use the planet gears rotation around themselves to power the extension and the planet gears orbiting the sun gear to control the angle, as seen in spur differential swerve

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T06:37:13.852Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":27.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/12","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659921,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T06:50:08.469Z","cooked":"

How?

In order to take the planet gears’ rotation, you need to either not let them orbit the sun gear, OR you need an extra carrier to pick up that rotation and get it out of the gearbox. The first is ruled out by your desire to use the planet gears orbiting to control angle. The second is extra complications, to put it mildly.

It sounds like what you’re trying to do is package a spur differential as a planetary. Different setups, different purposes. May work. May not.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T06:50:08.469Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":107,"readers_count":106,"score":26.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":72030,"username":"Ohad_shulman","name":"Ohad","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/13","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659922,"name":"Ohad","username":"Ohad_shulman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T07:20:31.012Z","cooked":"

the basic idea here is that when the ring gear and sun gear go in opposite directions, the planets orbit the sun gear, when the sun and ring gear spin opposite ways the planet gears will rotate in place. since the carrier is connected to the planets via bearing the planets can spin around themselves freely but when they orbit the sun the carrier spins. by doing this when the carrier spins the slides will pivot, and since the planet gears and the carrier spin around the sun together the output on the planet gears themselves remain in the same relative position to the slide, so using a set of bevels i can power the slides, the bevels here being connect to one of the planet gears via shaft goingthrough the carrier. and of course when the sun and ring gears arent on either extremes there is a differential of the two motions described here.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T07:20:31.012Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":100,"readers_count":99,"score":25.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/14","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659923,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T07:55:47.454Z","cooked":"

OK, so let me get this straight. You’re adding bevel gears to the planet gear shafts. These bevel gears connect to a shaft that runs through the carrier. This shaft runs one of the two functions, while the normal carrier runs the other.

“Your scientists were so preoccupied with whether they could, that they forgot to ask whether they should.” Or something like that.

Is it possible? Barely. You’re going to to take a look at the link I posted earlier. (You haven’t yet. GO.)

In addition to the normal nested shaft considerations* that make me strongly warn people about NOT using them if there’s an alternative, there’s three possible problems that I can see that you’ll need to think about.
a) Planetary gearboxes have very little extra space in a stage. Therefore, this is going to need to be a custom build, with a larger-than-typical sun gear (and carrier). Not too big of an issue, with the right tools.
b) The typical maximum single-stage reduction for just about any spur or planetary gearbox** is 10:1. If either the extension or the angle requires more than that, you need to figure out how to do this across multiple stages. That’s going to get very ugly, very fast. The easy workaround is that one or both motors gets an extra gearbox going in… and the next obvious question is “so why not just use two gearboxes?”
c) Assume that one of the two directions of motion is in a hard stop and can no longer move in a given direction. This will obviously affect the motion of the planet gears in some way given that one of the ways they can possibly move is now gone–you’re going to need to figure out how to compensate for that. Locked carrier in one direction is workable. Locking the planetary gears in one direction? Could be exceptionally bad.

*Nested shafts can be very particular about their design and functionality, even for a “simple” spin-in-spin independent. The single biggest thing to remember is that any power transmission that requires going from the inner shaft through the outer shaft is Right Out. Gotta go beyond the ends of the outer. I have experience doing nested shafts–I don’t suggest doing that unless there is no other option that will work.
**Harmonic gearboxes and their very close relatives are exceptions.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T07:55:47.454Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":94,"readers_count":93,"score":23.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":72030,"username":"Ohad_shulman","name":"Ohad","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/15","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659925,"name":"Ohad","username":"Ohad_shulman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T08:47:00.462Z","cooked":"

Capture792×781 232 KB

this is my initial sketch, the blue is the carrier, green is ring gear,yellow is sun gear and red is planet gears, the planet gears have a shaft going through them that extends through the holes in the carrier, those are bearings so it moves freely around itself. it wont be anywhere near 1:10 hopefully, at most 1:2. and i have thought of whether i should, i shouldnt and it wont be good but itll be cool and i wanna do the experiment. and if one of the motions is locked for some reason that means something has already gone catastrophically wrong since there should only be 1 hard stop for the carrier and at that point i can stop it from ruining itself in the code with a magnet sensor to detect when it hits the hard stop. and i have read the wikipedia for it but they dont have anything on using it the way i want to.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T08:47:00.462Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":93,"readers_count":92,"score":23.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/16","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659927,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T09:04:22.101Z","cooked":"

You will need to write out the kinematics for every relevant coupling between gears and bodies, and then solve the big matrix equation you will get as a result. Do note that internal gears spin in the same direction unlike external gears.

paulonis:

I’m curious if this question is related to something planned to be used on an FTC robot or if it’s some other kind of assignment or educational challenge. Either way, it’s stunning that this is a question at the high school level.

FTC teams fairly often do wild things in the name of packaging for better or for worse (I’ve seen many examples of weird stuff being done well and poorly).

paulonis:

It may be helpful to chat with Copilot or your favorite AI assistant about this topic. I gave it a try in Copilot and found the answers to be pretty solid. I think the initial question is a bit under-specified, so exploring the problem space with clarifying prompts might quickly generate some answers for the complete question.

I do not recommend using AI for most technical work. It is very frequently wrong and if you do not know what you are doing, you won’t be able to know if its wrong. (And if you do know what you are doing, you can just do it).

Ohad_shulman:

Capture792×781 232 KB

this is my initial sketch, the blue is the carrier, green is ring gear,yellow is sun gear and red is planet gears, the planet gears have a shaft going through them that extends through the holes in the carrier, those are bearings so it moves freely around itself. it wont be anywhere near 1:10 hopefully, at most 1:2. and i have thought of whether i should, i shouldnt and it wont be good but itll be cool and i wanna do the experiment. and if one of the motions is locked for some reason that means something has already gone catastrophically wrong since there should only be 1 hard stop for the carrier and at that point i can stop it from ruining itself in the code with a magnet sensor to detect when it hits the hard stop. and i have read the wikipedia for it but they dont have anything on using it the way i want to.

Lets ignore the fact that making differentials is hard. Lets also ignore that controlling them is harder. Even if you make a very nice differential, I would not recommend this setup because of stiffness and backlash. The slides create a long lever arm with its CG fairly high off the ground, which will result in the elevator deflecting significantly if the robot accelerates or gets hit. Due to the many small parts in planetary gearboxes, they also don’t tend to be very stiff torsionally, which is really bad when you have a long arm attached to it.

Differentials have more backlash than just driving each mechanism individually, which is incredibly bad for this mechanism, as this makes controlling the mechanism extremely hard (borderline impossible) to control nicely. Backlash and poor stiffness result in significant time losses in cycling due to the mechanism just not doing exactly what you (or your software) tells it to do, and is just problematic.

Ok now lets pretend the gearbox is somehow infinitely stiff with 0 backlash. This still would not perform much better than driving each mechanism individually due to viscous damping introduced by your lubricants. Because the speeds of both of your mechanisms are very different, you will have gears that move incredibly fast which introduce crazy amounts of viscous damping. FTC motors are not particularly strong and which will result in them bogging down significantly.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T09:04:22.101Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":3,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":97,"readers_count":96,"score":39.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/17","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659928,"name":"Ohad","username":"Ohad_shulman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/o/ecae2f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T09:18:24.926Z","cooked":"

for backlash, i dont know what its called but my team has learned how to control the motors in some weird way that makes it so the motors always fix to the position they want, maybe PID or something. controlling them should be fine (according to my programmer friend) but this is a cad exercise so control doesnt bother me, what makes a differential good? also from my experience with pivoting slides and where the motors here will be mounted, the CG wont actually be that high in the FTC scale so that isnt a problem for me. im also using herringbone gears which are very low backlash but im not sure. i have seen this mechanism used in my FRC teams differential swerve and it worked perfectly, this is powered by 4 motors so this will have nearly 100kgcm total. and i know it wont perform much better than a normal drive, but it saves me a motor and also its cool. im also ok with any other way to control the slides angle differentially this is just the one i thought of first

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":22,"updated_at":"2025-06-22T09:18:24.926Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":17,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":87,"readers_count":86,"score":22.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503473,"topic_slug":"planetary-gear-ratios","display_username":"Ohad","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50219,"username":"Alex_Y","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":72030,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead CADder"},"post_url":"/t/planetary-gear-ratios/503473/18","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3659929,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-06-22T09:35:57.087Z","cooked":"
Ohad_shulman:

for backlash, i dont know what its called but my team has learned how to control the motors in some weird way that makes it so the motors always fix to the position they want, maybe PID or something

This won’t help. Just because the motors say put doesn’t mean your mechanism will stay put. Backlash is like the single most annoying non-linearity when it comes to controls and you can’t control theory your way out of it, to the point where designers will spend tons of effort to reduce or eliminate it mechanically. The only way to fix it is mechanically.

Ohad_shulman:

also from my experience with pivoting slides and where the motors here will be mounted, the CG wont actually be that high in the FTC scale so that isnt a problem for me

The problem isn’t the robot tipping. The problem is that when your robot accelerates, huge moments will be placed on your gearbox which leads to large deflections. It doesn’t take that long of a lever arm for this to be problematic, and slides extended creates a huge moment arm. When combined with a gearbox that isn’t super stiff, this leads to the mechanism deflection a lot which results in incredibly poor performance. Stiffness is extremely strongly correlated to performance. I have never seen a robot with major stiffness issues do well, and have rarely seen stiff robots do poorly.

Ohad_shulman:

but this is a cad exercise so control doesnt bother me, what makes a differential good?

This is a bad line of thinking. “Not my problem” just leads to other people dealing with your problems, often poorly if they even can deal with it. Designers who go “not my problem” in this manner are bad designers. A good design does not introduce problems that are forced to be fixed in a suboptimal way (you can’t fix mechanical problems in code) and learning this habit is extremely bad practice. Sure you can learn how to do custom planetary gearboxes, but this is a bad excessive as you are also making a design that’s inherently bad in multiple ways. There are much better ways to learn how to do this.

Ohad_shulman:

i have seen this mechanism used in my FRC teams differential swerve and it worked perfectly,

Differential swerve in FRC has never outperformed coaixal swerve. The differential introduced too many control problems which erased the benefits of doing it in the first place.
